etymologies: early 20th century; earliest use found in Frederick Lanchester (1868–1946), car and aircraft designer and engineer. From ancient Greek ϕυγή flight + -oid, with the Greek word erroneously being taken as representing the sense of flight

definitions: Of or relating to the longitudinal stability of an aircraft or missile flying a nominally horizontal course in a vertical plane; specifically designating a slow fore-and-aft or pitching oscillation in which the flight path assumes the form of a series of shallow waves and the aircraft undergoes synchronous increases and decreases of speed.
